author: jgm
content: Vouch does something like this, although it focuses more on fetching the most up to date (but valid) data from multiple beacon nodes. Not entirely sure how you would decide two nodes have the same view of the beacon chain, as any two block proposals (for example) are usually different in terms of included attestations, at least.

author: ajsutton
content:
I could see that you could check they have the same parent block.  You'd still have the risk that you wind up choosing a block that's actually invalid but you wouldn't follow down that chain.  It's probably easier and far more reliable to detect the problem just by publishing the block you choose to all your beacon nodes and seeing if any reject it.

For attestations I imagine the key thing is just to check they agree on the source target - you might follow an invalid fork but not to the point of it finalizing. If you require the target or head to match you'll get a bunch of false positives just because some of your nodes got the block on time and some got it late.

author: jgm
content:
Yeah, it's the short-term instability as the chain is always "in motion", so to speak.

A while back I was playing with the concept of synthetic blocks, where data was contributed from each beacon node and Vouch ended up building its own block based on that data.  This is where that sort of majority-rule could come in to play, although I'd want to run a lot of numbers first to see what the reality was (e.g. how often the majority was behind the correct state, retrospectively speaking).
